reviewText:
Writing-wise, this game is a much-needed spit to the face towards all of the PC SJW moral thought police in existence. Gameplay-wise it's a welcome departure from the average modern military FPS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥... to a point. TBH some of the mechanics really don't feel as if they work together all that well and show the developmental hell this game went through.

Did it live up to the hype set by over a decade in development? ♥♥♥♥ no, but then again it wasn't trying to.
It's not the best game by any stretch of the imagination, but it sure as ♥♥♥♥ is fun. And that's the important thing.

reviewText:
An enjoyable mistake. This game really isn't as bad as people say it is. With great realistic creature design and good competent graphics. Amusing jokes and one-liners, keeping Duke's ego strong. And some pretty awesome weapons to blow the ♥♥♥♥ out of those alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with.

If you were to compare this game to Duke Nukem 3D, the game flops when it comes to level design a severe downgrade from the open level, secret filled levels of 'Duke Nukem 3D', changing it to a very linear scripted shooter. And there is a 2 weapon limit in place, meaning that you are unable to carry Duke's entire arsenal. Also regenerating health has been added making the gameplay ALOT less thrilling and ALOT more boring.

If you just want a game where you can be a total bad-♥♥♥ blowing the ♥♥♥♥ out of aliens, this is the game to play but be aware of its dated game design and problems

reviewText:
I played Duke Nukem 3D years ago and it was a really great shooter.

This sequel features decent-to-good level design, and a nice set of enemies to fight.

The gameplay is more modern since you cannot carry all weapons and your health refills along time.

One disappointing thing comes with the relative low efficiency of some weapons you imagined more potent (relative to the ego of the character), namely the revolver and the shotgun. So you end up gunning down aliens mostly with the triple cannon machinegun.

The story is purely decorative and the characters flat as a carpet. Half of the time the soldiers are coward and stupid, but that does not make Duke intelligent or brave.

It could have been a decent shooter but the game is blatantly sexist. Of course it comes with the character, but as far as I remember, all the female characters are either : horny at the mere sight of the Duke, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ providers, incapable of saving themselves, sex workers, alien surrogate mothers begging you to shoot them. I don't recall any female soldiers, scientists or civilians worth noticing. The developers pushed the envelope up to the following point : aliens are only abducting women, so you have to save them!

Is there an irony here? Maybe aliens are in fact abducting women to protect from the Duke? That would have been a hell of a twist!

So if you're confortable with that level of sexism, Duke Nukem Forever deserved a 6/7 as a shooter. Otherwise it's preferable to ignore it.

reviewText: Sometimes you find a random hidden gem while searching around the internet for interesting games to play, I stumbled across this one on Xhamster and decided I'd take a look and play it. I was pleasantly surprised! This game really is an unknown hidden gem. The gameplay is kind of lacking, some bits of the game are very stale, you could be doing *insert something awesome here* but still feel like you are quite bored. This I think is done on purpose to show how bored Duke Nukem is with having to deal with this stuff, all he wants is to get his rocks off and that's a tune we can all dance to. Anyways yatta yatta story etc but where the game really stands out is the art style, it is hard to put my fingers on them, but something stands out and quite striking and alluring compared to other games art styles. It has some sort of soft boldness to the style x2. Anyways great game everyone should check it out. I'd give it 8 prepubescent boners out of 10.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I gave it every chance in the world, and ignored every bit of criticism the game got. First, I'd like to say that at no point was it ever going to live up to the hype that was around the game. It could have came out and been the GOTY and still wouldn't have lived up to the buildup.

What the game does right is make long time fans of the franchise nostaligic for the classic games. All of the things that made you love Duke as a character are back. Sadly, the game is tedious to play. It's not fun or that challenging, but it's infuriating for all the wrong reasons. I don't care when games ♥♥♥♥ me off because they're hard. This one ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off because of the poor controls and glitches.

I can't recommend buying this game at full price. I would only buy it during a sale at a steep discount, and you'll probably regret not buying one of the other better Duke Nukem games. But if they announced a new Duke Nukem even after this game I'd buy it. Always bet on Douk.

reviewText: To be fair, there is some merit to this game. The environments and enemies look well enough, certainly not cutting edge but well past the limits of the sixth generation. There's even a small bit of platforming and puzzle solving, such as the remote control cars, running around in miniature, and bouncing inside an alien mother ship. There's lots of items strewn about with which the player can interact, like a fully functioning pinball machine, and boss fights usually depend on some gimmick instead of firepower.\nUnfortunately, none of these distractions are fully realized or satisfying, and only serve to interrupt very claustrophobic gun-play through narrow hallways and trenches. There a plenty of scripted set-pieces that reinforce this sense of linearity, creating spectacle at the expense of freedom, like being lifted by a crane or manning a turret against enemy spacecraft. I enjoy linear games, but the level design here did little to excite me.\nThe other big strike against this game is its personality. For instance, in Duke Nukem 3D, the titular protagonist was fairly quiet except for the occasional musing. Forever is packed with quips, but without any restraint or comedic timing. Lines like I've got balls of fail" or "Strange silicon-based life form" wear out their welcome immediately
date: and the title is full of such groaners.\nOther stabs at humor and shock value are more questionable. When playing through an organic alien lair
recommended: the walls are decorated with disembodied breasts. Here
hoursPlayed: the player finds abductees who have been implicitly ♥♥♥♥♥ and thus impregnated with enemy fetuses. The player may either euthanize these women or allow said monsters to incubate. While I can appreciate the "No-win" scenario
voteText: the whole scene felt extremely sadistic and underscores the problems with the game's mean-spirited attitude. I didn't buy Duke Nukem Forever to watch women suffer
helpfulPercent: and after having experienced that I generally feel worse as a person.\nBetween tedious game-play and troubling jokes
votesHelpful: I couldn't bring myself to finish it. It's a functional if not boring game stymied by what I consider to be poor taste. If you find yourself defensive or dismissive while reading my review
votesTotal: then you'll probably enjoy this game in part or full. I would not recommend this to anyone who enjoyed Duke Nukem 3D."

reviewText: Gameplay over graphics, no matter what anyone says. You'll get a thumbs down from me otherwise.\n\nI played DN1, 2, and 3D. I played a few of the old console ones too. DNF is like the late person to the party after it ended... 10 years ago. Had the potential to make a comeback, but somewhere along the line, they lost sight of a game that was always about sheer absurdity. It feels like they tried to copy elements from other games instead of inventing their own, or sticking to tried and true. Has the elements to be a good game, and they should have honestly just left the story out.

reviewText: I went into this game with extremely low expectations and was pleasantly surprised. This is a good game. It is not mindblowing, it is just another run-of-the-mill shooter, about as sophisticated as Call of Duty. There is hardly any story. It's all immature fart jokes and ♥♥♥♥. You can pick up ♥♥♥♥ and throw it. This is what you should expect from a Duke Nukem game.\n\nThe controls are tight, the level design is interesting but borders on tedious. The action is fast-paced but lacking. It won't take you long to finish. It's definitely not a memorable experience but it's not as bad as the gaming hivemind makes it out to be, it even got a couple laughs from me. If you want to truly enjoy this game, turn off your brain and pretend you're 12 years old again.

reviewText:
Ahhh, Duke Nukem Forever. The mythical game that was never to be released.

Sadly, it shouldn't of been. Duke Nukem had his time in the 90's; when his particular brand of macho humor was well appreicated and seen for the comedy it was. These days, however, Duke's practically trademark sense of humor is as outdated as it is offensive.

The game itself plays host to a variety of other mechanics seemingly lifted from other games; mechanics that have since been refined in others, but kept in a very raw form in this game. The overall impression being that the developers ran through a list of potentional game mechanics in a pick'n'mix fashion. That said, the developers have done a wonderful job of keeping the game stable, with no crashes or other problems noted.

But, if you can look past the seemingly poor gameplay mechanics, and the humor that is so awful it's actually insulting everyone rather than trying to make them laugh...you wind up with a liner first person shooter filled with the reanimated enemies of games long since past and very large amounts of womenfolk who really, REALLY need to put on some damn clothes. It feels like I've been sucked into a 14 year old's wet dream, to be frank.

This, it seems, is Duke's swan song. He needs to go back into retirement alongside his troupe of scantiliy clad women (that may or may not be aliens) as the gaming community wishes him well.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever suffers from one, fatal flaw: It didn't come out ten years ago and is roughly the same game you see now. The final build for the single player was apparently finished about two or three years ago by Triptych and 3D Realms. For whatever reason in licensing land the game has only surfaced now to be greeted with bad criticism, which is very understandable.

The single player is rather fun though, even if it does show how dated it already is. If you are to pick this game up, you really need to pretend that it came out back in 2009, or maybe even earlier if you want to give the game considerable leeway.

Try this game when it becomes a bargain bin title, as some concepts like the shrunken Duke sections are really neato, but in reality, the game becomes rather defunct once you've beaten the game.

Don't even bother with the multiplayer as dedicated servers haven't even been working since launch, which shows enough how much they cared about it.

reviewText: Welcome to the world of boring. Despite all the hype, Duke Nukem forever just felt like a dull shooter with loosely fitted together areas. 5 minutes in I realized it wasn't going to get any better, but regardless I dragged myself on to reach the lacklusture cliffhanger of an ending. reviewText: What a crass, unenjoyable load of crap this game is. The major problem with this game is that the unapologetic, brutish and ham-fisted experience is backed up with no substance or any sort of artistic direction. Full of pathetic jokes, flat and blind references, tasteless ignorance and disreputable design choices, this is not worth a sane person's time. While playing this game, you can tell there are 12 year olds out there giggling and clapping as Duke slaps a pair of ♥♥♥♥ on a wall. And that's all this is. It's not true misogyny when it's blurted out by some gun-totting man child with more ♥♥♥♥ jokes than sense. It's a painful, insulting experience that never holds water. Duke is made to be the Second Coming of Jesus Christ himself for no reason. He's an ignorant, brash and plain dimwit of a character with all the charm and charisma of a room full of shaved bears covered in ♥♥♥♥. The once golden humor of a man in a silly world filled with quirky enemy designs and kick ♥♥♥ weaponry has all but disappeared. Now it's simply distasteful and rushed. Gameplay is repetitive and boring, guns hold no weight, voice acting is meh (never liked the 'Duke' voice), animation is lack luster and story is near unbearable. I've found strains of plague that are far more appealing.

reviewText: The game had Duke humor to the core. It was a joy to see this back in action. Duke still had flare and style that only Duke can have. The Singleplayer  Campaign didn't take very long and was a joy to beat. To be warned there is nudity in this game and adult humor so if your sensitive to that kind of stuff then stay away from this game. The Multiplayer aspect of this game is still active and alot of fun to play with. There are separate in-game achievements for the Multiplayer side of the game. The graphics look not as crisp as today's game but it still does the job. The game is a must have for any Duke Nukem fan, it brings the old enemies into this game and puts more character into them. This was awesome to play and I really enjoyed it. Make sure to find this one on sale to earn Your Balls of Steel"."

reviewText:
My past history with Duke Nukem: I played the first Shareware Duke Nukem hundreds of times, as it was one of the few games I had on my IBM PS/2 (with a model M keyboard, I might add!). I did not play much of the Duke Nukem later series, nor did I play the Duke 3D very much.

I know that Duke Nukem Forever was one of the most hyped games of all times (tying with Half Life 3 and Starcraft 2). Perhaps it was the expectations that drove the reviews to be so critical. It's not a great game. It has some corny dialog. But as I played it, I enjoyed it. Perhaps bolstered by the low price tag and a little Jameson's, I've thought it was a great deal.

DNF is fun, as a standalone game. If you can pick it up on one of the frequent sales, it's worth playing.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever is a game you will either love or hate, depending on what expectations you had towards this sequel.

Haters will probably argue it's not a worthy successor to the series, it's unfinished, it's buggy, it's boring - and that might be true if you're desperately looking for reasons to hate the game.

Personally, I found DNF to be one of the most hilarious and funny games I've played in a while. This game does so many things right and has so much to offer to keep you entertained throughout the whole game, which will approx. last ~15 hours (including the DLC).

Boobs? Check.
Legendary Duke Nukem one-liners? Check.
Hilarious dialogues? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Interactive games inside the game? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Funny easter eggs? Check.
Boobs? Check.
Drivable forklifts? Check.
Boobs? Check.

DNF brings all the fun back into video games without taking itself or the video game industry too serious and that's something rare these days. If you're looking for some fun, buy DNF!

reviewText: While I'm recommending this game. Keep in mind that it is ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE. But I'm recommending it because I paid less than $5, it's Duke Nukem and surprisingly I've kept playing it. Despite being as bad as it is, it has a lot of the old charm of Duke Nukem 3D. I can see that this game was rushed out and could have been amazing as some parts are extremely polished, but most are lackluster. The graphics are ancient, the levels virtually empty, half the gameplay is absurdly stupid, the voice acting can't really be called acting and it's the most sexist games I've ever played. But because it's so bad, you just have to play it. If not for any other reason than a quick way (on easy) to bump up your achievement stats on Steam.

reviewText: I know, this game was developed for over 10 years. The critics say horrible things about it. But I don't care! The single player story was really fun and varied. It's designed as a continuous adventure, like Half-Life 2 and other modern games (so it's not split into levels). It puts you in the heat of the action with many big guns. It has some puzzle-ish elements too (again comparing to HL2), so it's more than just shooting. Not boring, nicely varied. Examples include driving a monster truck or jumping from a burger to burger in a kitchen while being shrunk. People seem to complain the most about being able to carry only 2 weapons. First of all... they've already added an option to carry 4 weapons, you can find it in the menu. But the game is completly playable and fun keeping the limit set to just 2. You find a lot of guns as you play. Rather than carry it all, find a new one, replace your low ammo weapon. You'll get enough opportunities to fire them all.

reviewText:
A very solid and enjoyable FPS game worth the price, or on sale if you're not sure.  Be the Duke in an action adventure FPS spanning Las Vegas to the Hoover Dam and more, if you have The Docter Who Cloned Me DLC that is, which feels more like the real ending to the game and is just as entertaining as the main game. Shoot pigcops, shout one-liners, bench press 600 pounds, throw stool, raise your ego meter, drink beer, take steriods, and more in one of the best FPS games ever made. If you enjoy FPS games, Half-Life, action movies, and Toy Story this game may be for you.


Whatever you do don't play if you're offended by everything otherwise you'll hate this game just as much as the militant anti-social justice warriors writing for sleazy hack media sites did when they slandered this game and the developers upon release due to it's usage of mild nudity, language, blood and gore, drugs and alcohol, and suggestive themes. The year is 2016, and my memory is blurred. Duke Nukem Forever surely isn't as bad as I remember, right?

Plowed through set piece after set piece until I was faced with a battle" with the grand mothership where Duke sat his sad little ♥♥♥ in a flimsy turret. Decided that this was the end of my revisit to DNF.

reviewText:
This game has problems, yes. There's no denying that. I mean, the humor of Duke Nukem was that we always knew he was a complete tool, but here, we're supposed to think he's actually a righteous dude. That makes his treatment of women, his terrible one-liners and everything else feel less like satire and more like, you know, things that are okay and cool. Certainly, that's one of the biggest cruxes here.

But as for everything else? I've never understood, and likely never will, the hatred the rest of this game gets. The level design is remarkably creative, and the core gameplay is visceral and satisfying. And while, perhaps, the graphics are a bit dated, good graphics don't make a good game. Ah, yes, and the sound design is actually pretty good as well. The guns sound great, the music is 90's cool, and Jon St. John delivers as Duke... as always.

So, yes, as a guy who considers myself a feminist, a lot of the humor is kind of screwed-up in a way that doesn't feel ironic, and that's definitely a knock against it in my book. But it doesn't make me hate the rest of the game. On a sale, if you can overlook some issues, this is a fine way to spend 8-10 hours, and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a fun, brainless shooter.

(For my full reviews and gaming news, check out digitaldevils.net!)

reviewText:
This game is really not as bad as people would have you believe. I played through it multiple times, and although it sometimes feels a little dated, the humour is spot-on. I anjoyed many of the mechanics and I definately enjoy many of the levels. The graphics are overall not something to write home about, but sometimes I did find myself pleasantly surprised by a certain scene or effect.

For those of you who played it and didnt think it lives up to the hype, remember, this game was more than a decade in the making, went through a lot of developer issues and outgrew 3 different game engines. Were lucky to have this at all. Also, I invite you to replay the original, it might give you an appreciation for how much they improved some aspects.

Buy it and support Duke, he's gonna need it if we want another one! I personally don't think you will be dissapointed!

reviewText:
After all the bashing reviews, I feel obliged to recommend you DNF. I didn't give a fu*k about reviews and I had an oldschool blast.

Yes, the game is vulgar, highly NSFW and full of primitive one-liners. Not as great as old action movies but sometimes close.

I loved the old feeling - the old level design, weapons, and being stuck for some time which resulted in asking Internet for help on 2-3 occasions - which I really loved, reminded me of good old times. Also, game is quite hard, not like today's games are. Plus, million ingame minigames (pinball etc.).

Oh, and how much you will love boss fights! They're just awesome.

Pros - level design, boss fights, Duke, difficulty, minigames.
Cons - autoheal (but it's a little bit spiced up), some levels & something I can't remember.

It's not the best game out there and I'd be probably a little bit disappointed if I bought it on release date, but nowadays it's great FPS for a budget price, especially if you miss the gaming from 10 years ago.

Multi is actually really fun and old-schoolish, but hindered by some balance problems and a pathetic lack of some basic server options. Its worth $10 but I don't think Gearbox really deserves it for half-assing the multi and going to work on crappy DLC instead.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is not really as bad as a lot of people claim it is.  I do feel that it spends way too much time screwing around instead of letting you actually go out and shoot things.  There are entire chapters of the game that have no shooting and instead just have you wandering around looking for stuff or exploring an environment, and those can get boring very fast.  But when the game remembers that it's supposed to be a first person shooter and lets you shoot some aliens, it's still pretty fun for the most part.  I found the difficulty curve to be a bit off with the bosses;  one boss at around the 3/4ths mark was insanely hard, but then the next boss and the final boss were easy.  Overall, there is some fun to be had here, so if you see it on sale, grab it.  I got it for $10 and wasn't disappointed at that price.\n\nThis game does earn its M rating though, so be warned if any of the content mentioned in the ESRB decription would offend you.

reviewText:
15 years. We waited 15 years for this mindless slog. Maybe it's my age maturing (NAHH!!!), maybe it's that the game tries to be DUke Nukem 3d with modern graphics? Maybe cause it was terribly written, terribly directed and terribly made game that would have been more entertaining if never released so we can continue to speculate and make our own stories up,

this is just a bad game. Be prepared for limiting weapon choices that don't make much sense, don't actually work well and are so boring. Be prepared for running down straight corridors with no choices of any direction in a world that seems to be overly infatuated with Duke and his sexual exploits.

its very rare that a game was better off as vapour ware. But this is one of them.

If you're a Duke Nukem die hard, Find it on sale so that you can experience it. But the experience will leave you scratching your head wondering is this really how I remember him?". The one liners here are forced and overused. the sexual innuendo isn't remotely subtle like the first game
date: and the world is uninspired and unimaginative.\n\n"

reviewText: Leagues behind its predecessor in terms of level design and overall cohesion of gameplay but still a decent game and nowhere near the abomination that most of the press claims it to be. 8 guns in total (you can carry up to 4), gun management is bad (cycle only no keybinds for guns), levels are varied and there is a bit of platforming/puzzle gameplay in the mix. Campaign took me 11 hrs on hard to finish. The game takes a while to set the pace as the 1st couple of levels have you interacting with the environments/ playing mini-games but it gets progressively better. Difficulty feels uneven at times as there are some difficulty spikes here and there that slow down the pace at which you progress. The game throws a lot of references/ jokes at you with mixed results. Just don't expect highbrow humour from Duke.  All in all if you want to leave your brain at the door and play a fun game that has you chuckling along the way then this title is a prime candidate.

reviewText:
This game is really not as bad as people would have you believe. I played through it multiple times, and although it sometimes feels a little dated, the humour is spot-on. I anjoyed many of the mechanics and I definately enjoy many of the levels. The graphics are overall not something to write home about, but sometimes I did find myself pleasantly surprised by a certain scene or effect.

For those of you who played it and didnt think it lives up to the hype, remember, this game was more than a decade in the making, went through a lot of developer issues and outgrew 3 different game engines. Were lucky to have this at all. Also, I invite you to replay the original, it might give you an appreciation for how much they improved some aspects.

Buy it and support Duke, he's gonna need it if we want another one! I personally don't think you will be dissapointed!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Despite the negative press surrounding this game, it's a rather entertaining thrill-ride. No, it's not excellent by any means. If you expected the Second Coming of Christ from a franchise that's a pastiche of the mindless 80s action movie, you deserve the disappointment you got. But it's a solid shooter without the same tired premise as almost every other FPS series of the past two gens. Play the demo. If you like it, buy the game when it's on sale. It's a 6/10 game from a 6/10 franchise. Don't delude yourself that the other Duke Nukem games were any better.

reviewText: This game is one that was crushed by the weight of its own reputation. Make no mistake, it is not a great game or even a good game. It manages to be relatively entertaining in a crude way, despite a bevy of flaws that prevent this from being anything more than a $5 impulse purchase.  You have a game with uneven pacing, poor animations and dated graphics, iffy sound design and questionable levels of polish. The reality is that if this did not bear the Duke Nukem name it would be on no one's radar. It's worth playing simply to say you've played it, but you're going to need a few beers before it starts to make sense to actually pay money for this.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever. What can I say, well the answer to that is that it's a HUGE disappoinment.

When I first played the game I was heavily blinded by nostalgia, thus ignoring many of the games issues until I played through it the second time, to which only then did I realise what a colossal piece of sh*t this game was.

Negatives:
.Low quality textures for a modern game which is not surprising considering it uses the Unreal 2.5 engine but even than I've played games (such as MK vs DC universe) that have utilised the potential of the engine to higher standards
-For those who are console users I've heard that the console versions of the game suffered from texture pop-ins (essentially the textures are not rendered fast enough on whatever you appear to look at the time.
.Gameplay, rather than have the fast paced gameplay from its predocessor, DN Forever moves at a more sluggish pace similar to that of most modern FPS such as Halo or Call of Duty, even worse considering that when Duke sprints he tires out within 8 seconds.
.Regenerative health, aka. the Ego bar.
.Two weapon limit.
.Linear level designs, which eliminates level exploration.
.Boss battles are ridiculously easy as you are essentially given limitless supply of ammunition for the either the rocket launcher or the devastators.
.Terrible driving mechanics (not surprising since Gearbox were the ones to develop the driving mechanics)
.Terrible ending.
.Wall b**bs, WTF!

Positives:
Most of Duke's one liners are still awesome
From what I've seen from the expansion pack The Doctor who cloned me" it actually looks fun.
The fellow who is friends with Duke is rather funny even if some of his lines are vulgar.
The "Content" that a lot fans have wanted to see again in the series.

Overall the game was just a let down and I hope that when 3D realms (The creators of the Duke Nukem series) make the prequel to Duke Nukem 1 known as 'Duke Begins' that they learn from their mistakes so as to avoid making another DN Forever because every fan of the series does not want a bad Duke Nukem game
date: no fan does.\n\nOverall a 4 out of 10"

reviewText:
This is absolutely not what the fans were expecting, but it's actually not THAT bad. There are many flaws, like the fact that the single-player is full of useless things, the health (ego) recharges by itself, you can only carry 2 weapons and there is for sure not so much action like in Duke Nukem 3D. But it's fun to play.
The multiplayer was not designed for competitiveness, but for having fun when you have nothing to do. In fact, everybody can kill everybody.

In other words, if you want to kick asses, play Duke Nukem 3D. If you want to laugh, and not engage yourself, play Duke Nukem Forever.

6/10

reviewText: There are a lot of gameplay elements that I love in this game, and I hate that they're in something so profoundly marred.   Women only appear in this game as sexual objects.  That's been a core part of Duke Nukem since at least 3D, but that doesn't make it OK.  And it ends up going past sexism and into misogyny.  Then you reach the Hive level and mix in body horror; it's disgusting in ways I don't think the developer intended.\n\nThat's too bad, because I really enjoyed the actual gameplay.  The basic shooting mechanic was a lot of fun.  I never got bored during the enemy encounters.  Some were really frustrating, but I was always able to get through by changing tactics.  It's full of great interactive bits like working air hockey and pinball games.  I was laughing so hard when I started drawing on a whiteboard and an NPC commented on it.  The later half of the game that was all about fighting aliens and making references to games and movies I like was great.  I wish they'd just done that.  Then I could give it a whole-hearted thumbs-up.

reviewText: What a bummer! I wanted to LOVE this game. 20 minutes in I figured I would settle for just liking the game (after all there was a lot of promise of T and A). But there is a serious lack of oomph behind anything in this game. In a genre that is as saturated as FPS you need more than just nostalgia for 10 year old game. The dialogue... it's hard to describe how flat it is. I remember when the original first came out. I was blown away by the sound effects and Duke Nukem talked! It was amazing, but standards have changed since Duke first came on the scene and the devs fell short. I hate giving a thumbs down to a game especially one I haven't completed but with all the games in my library and my limited time to play. I just can't force myself to play something I am not enjoying at all.\n

reviewText: No, I will not recommend this piece of garbage. Don't get me wrong, Gearbox probably tried their best to save this trainwreck, but so many years of development and the cult status of DN3D/Atomic meant only thing, this will not live up to the hype. And it didn't.\n\nDuke Nukem Forever is a huge step backwards and does not even live up to the quality standard of its predecessor.  And that is saying a lot for a sequel to a decade and a half old video game. Unejoyable, contrieved and hackneyed, with boring nad unispiring gameplay & level design. This attempt to remake Duke as a modern 21st century action hero is not worth your time or the effort.

There is absolutely no redeeming qualities for this game. 2 cents would be overpriced for this rubbish!

reviewText: This game is one that was crushed by the weight of its own reputation. Make no mistake, it is not a great game or even a good game. It manages to be relatively entertaining in a crude way, despite a bevy of flaws that prevent this from being anything more than a $5 impulse purchase.  You have a game with uneven pacing, poor animations and dated graphics, iffy sound design and questionable levels of polish. The reality is that if this did not bear the Duke Nukem name it would be on no one's radar. It's worth playing simply to say you've played it, but you're going to need a few beers before it starts to make sense to actually pay money for this.

reviewText:
Duke Nukem Forever. What can I say, well the answer to that is that it's a HUGE disappoinment.

When I first played the game I was heavily blinded by nostalgia, thus ignoring many of the games issues until I played through it the second time, to which only then did I realise what a colossal piece of sh*t this game was.

Negatives:
.Low quality textures for a modern game which is not surprising considering it uses the Unreal 2.5 engine but even than I've played games (such as MK vs DC universe) that have utilised the potential of the engine to higher standards
-For those who are console users I've heard that the console versions of the game suffered from texture pop-ins (essentially the textures are not rendered fast enough on whatever you appear to look at the time.
.Gameplay, rather than have the fast paced gameplay from its predocessor, DN Forever moves at a more sluggish pace similar to that of most modern FPS such as Halo or Call of Duty, even worse considering that when Duke sprints he tires out within 8 seconds.
.Regenerative health, aka. the Ego bar.
.Two weapon limit.
.Linear level designs, which eliminates level exploration.
.Boss battles are ridiculously easy as you are essentially given limitless supply of ammunition for the either the rocket launcher or the devastators.
.Terrible driving mechanics (not surprising since Gearbox were the ones to develop the driving mechanics)
.Terrible ending.
.Wall b**bs, WTF!

Positives:
Most of Duke's one liners are still awesome
From what I've seen from the expansion pack The Doctor who cloned me" it actually looks fun.
The fellow who is friends with Duke is rather funny even if some of his lines are vulgar.
The "Content" that a lot fans have wanted to see again in the series.

Overall the game was just a let down and I hope that when 3D realms (The creators of the Duke Nukem series) make the prequel to Duke Nukem 1 known as 'Duke Begins' that they learn from their mistakes so as to avoid making another DN Forever because every fan of the series does not want a bad Duke Nukem game
date: no fan does.\n\nOverall a 4 out of 10"

reviewText: Critics want this game to be hated, and I can see why. Duke is the least PC mainstream franchise, and it's akin to hanging out with that ex-jock dude from high school that hurls awful jokes all the time. But no matter how you wouldn't introduce the guy to your parents, SO, or people from work, you can't deny you mostly have fun with the guy. Sure, you switch your brain off, and you're not going to have any meaningful discussions with the guy any time soon, and it won't overall, turn you into a better person, but you have fun with the guy, and that's all that actually matters, that's the whole reason you hang out with him.\n\nTL;DR: Critics want you to hate this game, so they can appear more sophisticated, mature and feminist". Overall
